abstract.p: Footlights column reports on 18th Annual Welcome Back to Brooklyn Homecoming Festival, an exhibition in Southampton, LI, of works by artists associated with the poet Frank O'Hara, a concert by Valerie Capers and her quintet at Weill Recital Hall and and a five concert series by National Symphony Orchestra in Washington celebrating 300th anniversary of the piano; photos (M)

block.p: On a stage at Grand Army Plaza, the performers will include the Russian American Kids Circus, the Maimouna Keita School of African Dance and the rock singer Corey Glover. Outside the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Jewish and Afro-Haitian, calypso and soca rhythms will be heard. These and other attractions, including games, food and exhibitions and the coronation of the Brooklyn-born comedy team of Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara as homecoming king and queen, are part of the 18th Annual Welcome Back to Brooklyn Homecoming Festival. The event, from noon to 6 p.m. Sunday, is centered around Grand Army Plaza from Eastern Parkway to the Brooklyn Museum of Art and along Flatbush Avenue to the Prospect Park Wildlife Center.

Frank O'Hara (1926-1966) was a significant poet, a respected art critic and a curator at the Museum of Modern Art who lived in a circle of literary figures and artists. Beginning on Sunday, more than 100 works by 26 of these artists will be displayed at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, Long Island. Among them are Philip Guston, Jasper Johns, Alex Katz, Lee Krasner, Elaine de Kooning, Willem de Kooning, Alice Neel, Claes Oldenburg, Jackson Pollock and Larry Rivers. ''In Memory of My Feelings: Frank O'Hara and American Art'' continues through July 30.

She plays the piano. She sings. She composes. She is a professor emeritus at Bronx Community college. She is the jazz artist Valerie Capers, who will perform with her quintet at 8 tonight at Weill Recital Hall. The program, ''Encores Plus,'' consists of Broadway and pop standards and features a salute to Hoagy Carmichael in his centennial year.

If the answer is Bartolomeo Cristofori, what is the question? The question is: Who invented the piano? By 1700, Cristofori (1655-1731), an Italian keyboard instrument maker and designer associated with the Florentine court, is known to have created at least one keyboard instrument using the hammer method of striking the strings. To commemorate the 300th anniversary of his invention, Leonard Slatkin, the National Symphony Orchestra and guests will celebrate the piano with six concerts in five days. Beginning at 7:30 tonight at the Kennedy Center in Washington, pianists like William Bolcom, Sarah Davis Buechner, Joseph Kalichstein, Lambert Orkis, Peter Shickele and Sara Wolfensohn will play works for two and more hands, for multiple keyboards, for 12 pianos and for toy piano, as well as double and triple concertos and more.
